title: Econometrics 2
overview: Econometrics 2 introduces several classes of econometric models widely used in economic analysis, including dynamic regression models, multiple equation regression models, regression models with limited dependent variables, and regression models with panel data.

skill_outcomes.outcome_description: Recognize and understand the classification of common dynamic models: autoregressive models, distributed lag models.

skill_outcomes.skill_name: Understanding Short and Long Term Effects
skill_outcomes.outcome_description: Understand the meaning of short-term and long-term impact coefficients in dynamic models.
Understand the specification of multiple equation models and estimation methods.
Differentiate the mathematical-statistical nature of logit-probit models, ordinal logit models, multinomial logit models from linear regression models.
Understand the mathematical-statistical nature of regression models with panel data.
Relate economic, financial, and business research issues to econometric methods.
Determine the appropriate model form based on the nature of relationships between variables and the classification of dependent variables.
Use specialized software to estimate coefficients in models with specific data.

skill_outcomes.skill_name: Short and Long Term Impact Assessment
skill_outcomes.outcome_description: Evaluate the short-term and long-term impact of independent variables on continuous dependent variables.

skill_outcomes.skill_name: Impact Assessment in System of Equations
skill_outcomes.outcome_description: Evaluate the impact of independent variables on dependent variables in a system of equations.

skill_outcomes.skill_name: Impact Assessment for Discrete Dependent Variables
skill_outcomes.outcome_description: Evaluate the marginal impact of independent variables on discrete dependent variables.

skill_outcomes.skill_name: Impact Assessment Considering Fixed and Random Effects
skill_outcomes.outcome_description: Evaluate the impact of independent variables on dependent variables while considering both fixed and random effects of unobserved factors.
Be proactive in learning, research, and group work.
Be proactive in selecting issues, data, models, and using software for calculation and analysis.
Be proactive in presenting research results.
